===Etymology===
Uncertain, with many possible derivations. One of the more compelling explanations is that this is a compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=すさのお|すさ|tr1=susa|t1=roughness, wildness|pos1=root word unattested in isolation, but found in terms such as {{m|ja|凄まじい|tr=susamajii||terrible, dreadful}} or {{m|ja|荒む|tr=susamu||to be wild, to be savage}}|の|tr2=no|pos2=possessive particle|男|tr3=o|t3=man}}.<ref>p. 123{{lang|ja|日本文化の古層}} (''Nihon Bunka no Kosō'', “The Substrata of Japanese Culture”, in Japanese) by A. Slavic, Mirai-sha, [[w:Tokyo|Tōkyō]], 1984; ISBN 9784624200459: [http://books.google.com/books?id=crirHAAACAAJ http://books.google.com/books?id=crirHAAACAAJ]</ref> In this case, the kanji would be [[ateji]].

Another theory is that this may be a compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=すさのお|須佐|tr1=Susa|pos1=name of a place in Japan, where the god is supposed to have first touched earth|の|tr2=no|pos2=possessive particle|男|tr3=o|t3=man}}.<ref>{{lang|ja|神道の本：八百万の神々がつどう秘教的祭祀の世界}} (''Shintō no Hon: Happyaku-man no Kamigami ga Tsudou Hikyōteki Saishi no Sekai'', “The Shintō Book: The World of Esoteric Rituals, Crowded with 8 Million Gods”, in Japanese), [[w:Gakken|Gakken]], [[w:Tokyo|Tōkyō]], 1992; ISBN 9784051060244: [http://books.google.com/books?id=mWxrmgEACAAJ http://books.google.com/books?id=mWxrmgEACAAJ]</ref>
